verses.text: On the first day of the seventh month, you are to hold a holy assembly. You must not do any ordinary work. It is a day for blowing trumpets.
verses.comment: The blowing of trumpets signifies both joy and the call to worship, anticipating the fullness of worship revealed later in the New Covenant (see Heb. 12:22).

verses.text: You shall present a burnt offering as a pleasing aroma to the LORD: one young bull, one ram, and seven male lambs a year old, without blemish.
verses.comment: The symbolism of spotless animals continues to prefigure Christ as the perfect sacrifice (Heb. 9:14).

verses.text: With their grain offering of fine flour mixed with oil: three-tenths of an ephah for the bull, two-tenths for the ram, and one-tenth for each of the seven lambs.
verses.comment: The grain offerings express thanksgiving and dependency on God’s provision, hinting toward spiritual nourishment in the bread of life (John 6:35).

verses.text: Also one male goat as a sin offering, to make atonement for you.
verses.comment: The sin offering underscores the need for reconciliation with God, later fulfilled in Christ’s once-for-all sacrifice on the cross (Heb. 10:10).

verses.text: This is in addition to the burnt offering of the month, its grain offering, the regular burnt offering with its grain offering, and their drink offerings according to their rules, as a pleasing aroma, an offering by fire to the LORD.
verses.comment: Multiple offerings stress the richness of sacrificial worship; multiplicity of rites foreshadows the layered and sacramental worship in the age of fulfillment (see Mal. 1:11).

verses.text: On the tenth day of this seventh month you shall have a holy assembly, and you must humble yourselves. You shall not do any ordinary work.
verses.comment: This marks the Day of Atonement, a day of confession and penance, prefiguring the fullness of repentance in Christ (Acts 3:19).

verses.text: You shall offer a burnt offering to the LORD as a pleasing aroma: one bull, one ram, and seven male lambs a year old, all without defect.
verses.comment: Even in atonement, the emphasis on flawless offerings highlights the need for perfection in sacrifice, fulfilled by Christ (1 Pet. 1:19).

verses.text: With their grain offerings of fine flour mixed with oil: three-tenths of an ephah for the bull, two-tenths for the ram, and one-tenth for each of the seven lambs.
verses.comment: The specific measures show the reverence and orderliness in approaching God, reminding us that worship is never haphazard (1 Cor. 14:40).

verses.text: And one male goat as a sin offering, besides the sin offering of atonement, and the regular burnt offering with its grain, and their drink offerings.
verses.comment: This repetition of offerings emphasizes continual repentance and the longing for true forgiveness embodied in Christ (Rom. 8:3).

verses.text: On the fifteenth day of the seventh month you shall hold a holy assembly. You shall not do any ordinary work, and you shall keep a feast to the LORD for seven days.
verses.comment: This begins the Feast of Tabernacles, a time to remember God’s presence dwelling among His people, foreshadowing Christ as Emmanuel (John 1:14).

verses.text: You shall offer a burnt offering, a pleasing aroma to the LORD: thirteen young bulls, two rams, and fourteen male lambs a year old, all without defect.
verses.comment: The increase in offerings points to the abundance and generosity of God, encouraging full-hearted worship and anticipation of the great feast yet to come (Rev. 19:9).

verses.text: With their grain offering of fine flour mixed with oil: three-tenths of an ephah for each of the thirteen bulls, two-tenths for each of the two rams, and one-tenth for each of the fourteen lambs.
verses.comment: The measures suggest wholeness and completeness, connecting with the fullness of God’s provision and the spiritual food given in Christ (John 6:51).

verses.text: And one male goat as a sin offering, besides the regular burnt offering, its grain offering, and its drink offering.
verses.comment: Continual mention of sin offering reminds us that forgiveness is central to worship—pointing to the sacrificial heart of Christ’s work on the cross (Isa. 53:10).

verses.text: On the second day: twelve young bulls, two rams, fourteen male lambs a year old, all without defect.
verses.comment: Each day’s decreased offerings symbolize a journey toward spiritual fulfillment and hope for an unending feast with God, as found in the final restoration (Rev. 21:3).

verses.text: With their grain offering and drink offerings for the bulls, rams, and lambs, according to their number, as established by statute.
verses.comment: The fixed pattern reveals God’s order and faithfulness, and teaches us to approach Him in humility and obedience (1 Sam. 15:22).

verses.text: And one male goat as a sin offering, besides the regular burnt offering, its grain offering, and its drink offering.
verses.comment: The constancy of the sin offering expresses the depth of God’s mercy in forgiving the repentant, drawing hearts toward continuous conversion (Ps. 51:17).

verses.text: On the third day: eleven bulls, two rams, fourteen male lambs a year old, all without defect;
verses.comment: The repetition of purity required in offerings is a persistent reminder for believers to pursue holiness as God Himself is holy (1 Pet. 1:16).

verses.text: With their grain and drink offerings for the bulls, rams, and lambs according to their number, as established by statute.
verses.comment: Precise giving shows reverence and points to the spiritual discipline found in the rhythms of prayer and sacrificial giving (Heb. 13:15-16).

verses.text: And one male goat as a sin offering, besides the regular burnt offering, its grain offering, and its drink offering.
verses.comment: The sacrifices carry a spiritual lesson: We constantly need atonement and grace, as our human nature is frail and needs healing (Rom. 7:24-25).

verses.text: On the fourth day: ten bulls, two rams, and fourteen male lambs a year old, all without defect;
verses.comment: The gradual reduction of animals continues, indicating the movement toward completeness, similar to the spiritual growing in grace (2 Pet. 3:18).

verses.text: With their grain and drink offerings for the bulls, rams, and lambs according to their number, as established by statute.
verses.comment: Order and repetition in worship lead to deeper understanding and habit of devotion, as practiced faithfully by the earliest Christian communities (Acts 2:42).

verses.text: And one male goat as a sin offering, besides the regular burnt offering, its grain offering, and its drink offering.
verses.comment: Continued emphasis on sin offerings demonstrates God’s ongoing call to repentance and spiritual renewal (Eph. 4:22-24).

verses.text: On the fifth day: nine bulls, two rams, fourteen male lambs a year old, all without defect;
verses.comment: The sustained attention to perfect sacrificial animals invites reflection on striving for wholeness and dedication in one’s spiritual life (Phil. 3:12-14).

verses.text: With their grain and drink offerings for the bulls, rams, and lambs according to their number, as established by statute.
verses.comment: The repetition builds a rhythm of worship, showing how regular devotion transforms the heart (Col. 3:16).

verses.text: And one male goat as a sin offering, besides the regular burnt offering, its grain offering, and its drink offering.
verses.comment: Sin offering alongside other sacrifices reflects the importance of both atonement and thanksgiving in a balanced spiritual life (Ps. 50:14).

verses.text: On the sixth day: eight bulls, two rams, fourteen male lambs a year old, all without defect;
verses.comment: The decrease continues, mirroring spiritual development and preparation for a final consummation in God’s kingdom (Luke 22:16-18).

verses.text: With their grain and drink offerings for the bulls, rams, and lambs according to their number, as established by statute.
verses.comment: This orderly approach shapes a discipline of worship, which is central to living out faith in all circumstances (Rom. 12:1).

verses.text: And one male goat as a sin offering, besides the regular burnt offering, its grain offering, and its drink offering.
verses.comment: Forgiveness remains at the center of corporate worship, and this prioritization anticipates the priority of the forgiveness of sins in Christian liturgy (Matt. 26:28).

verses.text: On the seventh day: seven bulls, two rams, and fourteen male lambs a year old, all without defect;
verses.comment: Seven is the biblical number of completion, showing that the feast is a foretaste of eternal rest in God’s presence (Heb. 4:9-11).

verses.text: With their grain and drink offerings for the bulls, rams, and lambs according to their number, as established by statute.
verses.comment: Meticulous worship rites reinforce God’s absolute holiness and our call to reverence (Heb. 12:28).

verses.text: And one male goat as a sin offering, besides the regular burnt offering, its grain offering, and its drink offering.
verses.comment: Maintaining the sin offering points both to human need and God’s mercy, preparing for the revelation of Christ as the Lamb (John 1:29).

verses.text: On the eighth day you shall hold a solemn assembly. You shall not do any ordinary work.
verses.comment: The final assembly marks the completion and renewal, a fitting image of resurrection, new creation, and spiritual rebirth in Christ (2 Cor. 5:17).

verses.text: You shall offer a burnt offering, a pleasing aroma to the LORD: one bull, one ram, seven lambs a year old, all without defect;
verses.comment: Numbers are scaled down, indicating a culmination and rest—an echo of Christ’s one perfect sacrifice which fulfills all (Heb. 9:26).

verses.text: With their grain and drink offering for the bull, ram, and lambs, according to their number, as established by statute.
verses.comment: Faithfulness in worship rituals helps to build the spiritual life, training the soul to walk in reverence (Ps. 119:105).

verses.text: And one male goat as a sin offering, besides the regular burnt offering, its grain offering, and its drink offering.
verses.comment: Sin offering, even at the close, highlights that forgiveness is ultimately realized in God’s grace made manifest for all (Titus 2:11-14).

verses.text: These you shall offer to the LORD at your appointed feasts, in addition to your vow offerings and your freewill offerings, for your burnt offerings, grain offerings, drink offerings, and peace offerings.
verses.comment: The abundance of offerings, both mandated and voluntary, shows grateful hearts and invites deeper participation in God’s covenant love (Rom. 12:1-2).

verses.text: Moses told the Israelites all that the LORD had commanded him.
verses.comment: Obedience to God's revelation through appointed mediators is necessary; points forward to ultimate obedience through Christ, the final prophet and king (Heb. 1:1-2).

verses.text: Summary: All offerings for the days of the Feast are in addition to your regular daily burnt offerings, with their grain and drink offerings.
verses.comment: Daily sacrifices establish a foundation of worship, and the extra offerings elevate the feast, pointing toward the heights of spiritual worship found in communal liturgy (Rev. 4:8-11).

verses.text: You must observe these instructions at your feasts, presenting offerings made by fire, with pleasing aroma to the LORD, together with your regular offerings and all your vows and voluntary gifts.
verses.comment: Worship is both regular and spontaneous—demonstrating that faith is meant to permeate all aspects of life with ordered regularity and generous devotion (Phil. 4:18).

verses.text: So Moses communicated all these instructions from the LORD to the people of Israel.
verses.comment: Moses’ mediation prefigures the role of authoritative teaching in the community of faith, guiding God’s people to true worship and unity in Him (John 17:21).
